title: Climate missing "AUTO": bug or Matter limitation?
body:
Hi,
not clear to me if the missing "auto" functions on HAMH exposed climates is about a Matter standard current limitation or.. if it's a HAMH bug.

You can find OFF, Heat, Clool but not AUTO.
KC

P.S: of course under Home Assistant the Climate entity HAS the AUTO setting.
author: KC-inDomus

comments.body:
Unfortunately the definitions of "auto" are not matching between matter and home assistant:

Auto in Matter:
Automatically switch between heat and cool based on the target and current temperature.
Therefore heat AND cool feature is required for a device to support auto.

Auto in Home Assistant:
The device is taking control. It doesn't neccessarily mean "heat & cool".

The `heat_cool` feature in Home Assistant does actually match the "auto" in Matter.

> Unfortunately the definitions of "auto" are not matching between matter and home assistant:
> 
> Auto in Matter: Automatically switch between heat and cool based on the target and current temperature. Therefore heat AND cool feature is required for a device to support auto.
> 
> Auto in Home Assistant: The device is taking control. It doesn't neccessarily mean "heat & cool".
>

So - as usual, I migh say - Matter is disappointing. So we have to wait that someone realizes that auto function is a must have on a smart thermostat.

title: Fix_light_level_math
body:
Since the brightness in home assistant entity is stored as an integer and matter passes the value as an integer, but with slightly different max, we must round it to the closest value when converting.

This causes incorrect values in consumer solutions such as the below.
1. 10% = Matter 25 = converted 25.098425196850396 = homeassistant 25 = converted back 24.901960784313725 = Matter 24 = 9%
2. 90% = Matter 229 = converted 229.9015748031496 = homeassistant 229 = converted back 228.101960784313725 = Matter 228 = 89%

title: [Question] Entity Name Replaced by Identifier String
body:
I'm encountering an issue with the entity name when it contains special characters or exceeds a certain length. Specifically, my Home Assistant entity originally named "Luz da Cama - Quarto do Guilherme" is exposed in Matter as "Luz da Cama - Quarto do 0e5caab0".

Could you confirm if this behavior is intended or if there is a bug that causes part of the name to be replaced by an identifier? Additionally, if there are specific naming guidelines or restrictions for entities in Matter, that information would be very helpful.

Thank you for your assistance!
author: joaopedros2

comments.body:
Yes, this is intended.
The `nodeLabel` cannot be longer than 32 characters.

So if the name is shorter than or equal to 32 chars, it is used.
If it is longer than 32, only the first 24 chars are used and a 8 char hash is added instead. Having that, users are always able to identify it with the User Interface. At least in Alexa you can rename your devices (locally for Alexa only). I thought this is possible for the others, too, so I thought its fine.

While thinking about it, I'll change it to 28 chars and a 4 char hash, but anyway the root cause remains.

title: Reliability Issues with Google Assistant Matter Hub at High Device Count without Exclude Rules
body:
**Problem Description:**

When using the Matter Hub via Google Assistant, reliability issues occur if a large number of devices are added without setting exclude rules. This significantly reduces the reliability of device control, leading to inconsistent performance.

**Expected Behavior:**

The Matter Hub should operate reliably with Google Assistant, regardless of the number of devices added, without requiring specific exclude rules.

**Actual Behavior:**

When many devices are added without exclude rules, the Matter Hub performs inconsistently through Google Assistant. Devices often do not respond or only respond sporadically to commands.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

Add multiple devices of different types (e.g., binary_sensor, sensor, switch, lock, etc.).
Configure the Matter Hub without any exclude rules.
Attempt to control devices through Google Assistant.
Observe that devices often do not respond as expected.
Resolution Steps Taken:

I excluded binary_sensor, sensor, switch, and lock devices, and since then, all lights have been responding reliably.

**Question:**

Is there a maximum device threshold before reliability is affected? If so, it would be helpful to document this limit.

**Environment:**

- Matter Hub version: Alpha 26
- Device types not in use: binary_sensor, sensor, switch, lock, lights
- Platforms: Home Assistant, Google Assistant
author: steuerlexi

comments.body:
I cannot even say if it’s a performance issue of Google Home or of the matter hub. Additionally your HA server hardware which runs the addon can be a limiting factor when including that much entities.

Since matter hub is not a part of home assistant, it subscribes to entity states using the websocket api of HA.
Every changed entity triggers the change detection of matter hub and needs to be reflected to matter. I know there are one or two places I can improve performance, but I doubt that it will solve this issue.

What do you need that much devices in google home for? How many of them do you actually control using google home?

I've realized that I currently have 390 devices when I include the switch domain, but I definitely don’t need that many switches! I'll need to refine the include filter, which should help manage the device count effectively.
For me using a label is most useful way of only including what I want to control via voice.

title: [Enhancement] Allow editing bridge configurations
author: t0bst4r

comments.body:
By changing the config so that devices are added or removed in the hub, how will that impact the assistant device?
Meaning will they automatically be added or removed from it as well?

Yes and no, I tested that with Alexa by using a label to include entities. By adding or removing the label to another device and restarting the addon you can achieve the edit functionality. 

When adding an entity (and restarting the addon) Alexa automatically finds the new devices after some minutes. You can force it manually by asking to search for devices. But that is not necessary. 
When removing a device it does not disappear from Alexa. Instead it gets "unreachable" and you need to remove it by hand.
